Research Paper Potassium modified La-Mg mixed oxide as active and selective catalyst for mono-methylation of phenylacetonitrile with dimethyl carbonate Jayaram Molleti Ganapati D. Yadav ⁎ Department of Chemical Engineering, Institute of Chemical Technology, Nathalal Parekh Marg, Matunga, Mumbai, 400 019, India Department of Chemical Engineering Institute of Chemical Technology Nathalal Parekh Marg Matunga Mumbai 400 019 India ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Mono-methylated products of phenyl acetonitrile (PAN) are in demand for the preparation of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAID) such as Ketoprofen, Ibuprofen and Naproxen. 2-Phenylpropionitrile is prepared from PAN and finds uses in pharmaceutical industry. Herein, we report a novel catalyst potassium promoted lanthanum-magnesium oxide as well as a novel reaction using it. It is used for the first time for the selective mono-methylation of phenylacetonitrile to 2-phenylpropionitrile with dimethyl carbonate as a methylating agent. A variety of catalysts were synthesized, characterized such as MgO, La2O3, La2O3-MgO and potassium (1–4wt%) on La2O3-MgO and used in mono-methylation of phenylacetonitrile with dimethyl carbonate (DMC). Two wt% K/La2O3-MgO catalyst was the best and showed 100% conversion of phenylacetonitrile and 100% selectivity of 2-phenyl propionitrile at mole ratio of PAN: DMC of 1:30 at 150°C in 2h. The characterization of fresh and used 2wt% K/La2O3-MgO was done using different techniques such as FTIR, SEM, TGA-DSC, CO2-TPD, XRD, and BET surface area analysis. Two wt% K/La2O3-MgO catalyst was used to study the reaction mechanism and a kinetic model developed using LHHW type of mechanism with all species being weakly adsorbed. The apparent activation for mono-methylation of phenylacetonitrile to 2-phenylpropionitrile was found to be 13.77kcal/mol. Keywords Mono-methylation Dimethyl carbonate Phenylacetonitrile 2-Phenyl propionitrile K/La2O3-MgO Mixed metal oxide Nomenclature A Pheyl acetonitrile (PAN) B Dimethyl carbonate (DMC) AS Chemisorbed PAN BS Chemisorbed DMC C 2-Phenyl propionitrile (2-PPN) S Vacant site CA Concentration of PAN in mol/cm3 CB Concentration of DMC, mol/cm3 CAo Initial concentration of PAN in bulk liquid phase (mol/cm3) CBo Initial concentration of DMC in bulk liquid phase, mol/cm3 CBS Concentration of DMC at catalytic site S, mol/cm3 CC Concentration of 2-PPN, mol/cm3 CCS Concentration of 2-PPN at catalyst site S, mol/cm3 CS Concentration of vacant sites, mol/cm3 CT Total concentration of sites, mol/cm3 kR2 Reaction rate constant, cm6 mol−1 g-cat−1 s−1 Ki Adsorption equilibrium constant for species i, cm3/mol W Product species W, methanol w Catalyst loading g/cm3 of the liquid volume XA Fractional conversion of A -rA Rate of reaction of A, molcm3 s-1 k 1 Pseudo-first order reaction constant, cm3 g-cat-1 s-1 1 Introduction Developing strategies for the synthesis of fine chemicals using economical and environmentally clean process is a current trend. Most of these technologies employ homogeneous catalysts, which are difficult to recover and recycle. Hence, substitution of homogeneous catalysts by heterogeneous catalysts is essential to make the process green [1]. Over the years, various solid bases have been used for the production of fine chemicals [2–4]. During the past few years, mono-methylated products of phenyl acetonitrile (PAN) have been used for the preparation of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAID) such as Ketoprofen, Ibuprofen and Naproxen. These are commercially well known drugs and used to treat pain, swelling, fever and inflammation [5,6]. In chemical and allied industry, base catalyzed mono-methylation of methylene-active compounds using usual methylating agents (methyl halides or dimethyl sulfate) is not easy because the reaction mainly proceeds towards the formation of dimethyl derivatives [7,8]. These methylating agents are toxic, corrosive and the methods require a stoichiometric amount of strong base to neutralize acidic by-products. Hence, there is a need to develop processes based on heterogeneous catalytic materials and green alkylating agents. Dimethyl carbonate (DMC), which is a green, safe and cheap reagent, has been reported as a potential methylating agent [5]. Therefore, DMC is considered as an environmentally friendly substitute for the hazardous methylating reagents [9]. The synthesis of 2-phenylpropionitrile (2-PPN) by mono-methylation of PAN with DMC had been extensively investigated using phase transfer catalysts (PTC). Tundo et al. [10–12] reported 99.5% 2-PPN selectivity for the reaction of PAN with DMC using gas liquid PTC and homogeneous catalysts (organic bases and alkali metal carbonates). However, there are still major problems associated with homogeneous catalytic systems such as separation, recovery and recycle. Fu and Ono [13] reported vapour phase mono-methylation of PAN with methanol as an alkylating agent using alkali-exchanged zeolites. Normally, zeolite catalysts require higher reaction temperature and produce various side products. Singh et al. [14] reported 98.4% conversion of PAN and 92% selectivity to 2-PPN with DMC using NH2-Na-Al-MCM-41catalyst for 10h at 180°C. Kaneda et al. [15] reported mono-methylation of PAN over Ru/hydrotalcite (HT) catalyst at 180°C with 98% yield of 2-phenylbutyronitrile using ethanol as a methylating agent at higher reaction time (20h). However, these reported catalysts are not favorable due to harsh condition and long reaction time. Thus, development of highly active, stable and recyclable catalyst for the efficient synthesis of 2-PPN is highly desired. In the past two decades, mixed metal oxides have been widely used as solid base catalysts due to their unique chemical and physical properties [16]. Lanthanum oxide (La2O3) is one of the strongest basic oxides but it has low activity due to its low surface area. The activity of La2O3 is increased when it mixed with magnesium oxide (MgO) due to increasing basicity [17,18]. Mg-La mixed oxide was reported in various chemical reactions like Wadsworth-Emmons reaction [19], transesterification reaction [20], Wittig reaction [21], synthesis of glycerol carbonate [22], Michael addition reaction [23] and epoxidation of olefins [24]. Stronger basic sites are generated with the loading of alkali or alkaline earth metal on the support materials [25]. Several researchers reported that the use of potassium precursors like KOH [26], K2CO3 [27], KNO3 [28–31] and KF [32] can help the formation of solid super base. A number of base catalyzed reactions using hydrotalcite, supported hydrotalcite, mixed metal oxides and supported mixed oxide have been studied for industrially important reactions in our laboratory [33–36]. Recently, Yin et al. [37] reported solvent-free Knoevenagel condensation over 10wt% KOH/La2O3-MgO as a solid super base. In the current work, we synthesized solid base catalyst using La-Mg mixed oxide as support and potassium as a modifier. We report an environmentally friendly procedure for highly selective mono-methylation of PAN using DMC over 2wt% K/La2O3-MgO catalyst at 150°C (Scheme 1 ). The catalyst activity was compared vis-a′-vis various solid base catalysts such as MgO, La2O3 and La2O3–MgO with different loadings of potassium. The fresh and spent 2wt% K/La2O3-MgO catalysts were characterized by various techniques. The effects of different parameters were studied systematically to establish the reaction mechanism and kinetics. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals Phenyl acetonitrile (PAN) and dimethyl carbonate (DMC) were procured from SD Fine Chemicals Ltd., Mumbai. Magnesium nitrate, Lanthanum nitrate, urea, and potassium carbonate were procured from Thomas Baker Chemicals, Mumbai. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Lanthanum-magnesium mixed oxides (La2O3-MgO) with different mole ratios of La and Mg were prepared by a hydrothermal method using urea as a precipitating agent [34]. The role of urea as a precipitating agent is well described by Ogawa et al. [38]. The typical process for the synthesis of La:Mg with 1:3 molar ratio is as follows: 2.1gLa (NO3)3·9H2O, 3.86gMg (NO3)3·H2O and 6gurea were dissolved in 150mL distilled water and stirred for 1h until the solution became homogeneous. Then it was transferred into a Teflon lined bomb reactor which was heated at 160°C for 12h in a muffle furnace. The solid material was washed with distilled water. After filtration, it was dried at 120°C. MgO and La2O3 catalysts were prepared by the same procedure as described earlier and calcined at 650°C for 4h. Potassium modified La2O3-MgO was prepared by wet impregnation method. The required quantity of potassium carbonate was dissolved in 2mL water. The resultant solution was added to 1g La2O3-MgO via wet impregnation technique, under vigorous agitation at 80°C. On completion of adsorption of potassium solution onto the surface of mixed oxide, the resultant solid was dried at 100°C for 10h and calcined at 750°C for 4h in air. Different catalysts were prepared with potassium on La2O3-MgO by taking the appropriate amount of precursor and support and named as 1wt% K/La2O3-MgO, 2wt% K/La2O3-MgO, 3wt% K/La2O3-MgO and 4wt% K/La2O3-MgO. 2.3 General procedure for methylation of PAN All experiments were carried out in a 100mL autoclave (Amar Equipments, Mumbai, India) equipped with pitched turbine impeller and controllers for pressure and temperature. In a standard experiment the following were added: 0.034mol of PAN, 1.025mol of DMC and 0.2mL of n-decane as an internal standard with a catalyst loading of 0.03g/cm3 in total volume (30cm3) of the liquid. The reaction mass was heated at 150°C and 1000rpm for 2h. 2.4 Method of analysis Samples were withdrawn periodically from the reaction mass and analyzed by GC equipped with a capillary column BPX-50 (length 30m and inner diameter 0.25mm) and FID detector. Product confirmation was carried out by GC–MS (Perkin Elmer, Clarius model 500 on an Elite-1 capillary column of length 30m and inner diameter 0.25mm). The conversions were based on the limiting reagent, PAN. After the reaction was completed, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature and the reaction mass filtered to separate the catalyst. The catalyst was washed with methanol (5mL×2) to ensure that no product was adsorbed on the catalyst. The filtrate was collected and the solvent evaporated under reduced pressure to obtain the oily product, which was confirmed by GC–MS. 2.5 Characterization methodology Catalysts were characterized by different techniques. The detailed description of characterization methodology is published in recent literature [39]. Details are also provided in supplementary information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 XRD The XRD patterns of La2O3-MgO and K/La2O3-MgO with different wt% loadings of potassium are depicted in Fig. 1 . La2O3-MgO (Fig. 1 (a)) catalyst showed the presence of La2MgOX (JCPDS: 42-339), La2O3 (JCPDS: 40-1281) and MgO (JCPDS: 27-759). The existence of La2MgOX confirms the interaction between the La2O3 and MgO constituents during the synthesis of La2O3-MgO [18,40]. All potassium loaded catalysts showed similar XRD patterns of La2O3-MgO because potassium can be well dispersed on the La2O3-MgO support. Fig. 1 (b), (c), (d), (e) and (f) shows no typical diffraction peaks corresponding to the K2CO3 (2θ=12°,25°, 32°,38° and 41°), which suggest that potassium carbonate has completely decomposed. With the loading of potassium, there is disappearance of the La2O3 peak at 2θ=30.36° and the detection of new peak is attributed to K2O (JCPDS: 27-431) [41,42]. This K2O phase maybe the origin of basicity and high catalytic activity. The crystalline size of the La2O3-MgO and 2wt% K/La2O3-MgO was calculated using Scherrer’s formula. The average crystallite size of La2O3-MgO and 2wt% K/La2O3-MgO was 15.16nm and 30.89nm, respectively. The XRD pattern of 2wt% K/La2O3-MgO and reused catalysts were compared to find that they were almost the same which confirmed that prepared catalyst was stable. 3.1.2 FTIR Fig. 2 shows FT-IR spectra of La2O3-MgO, 1wt% K/La2O3-MgO, 2wt% K/La2O3-MgO, 3wt% K/La2O3-MgO, 4wt% K/La2O3-MgO and reused 2wt% K/La2O3-MgO catalyst. 2wt% K/La2O3-MgO catalyst showed strong band at 650cm−1, which is attributed to the lattice vibration of lanthanum oxide bond. The band at 3650cm−1 indicates the presence of hydroxide species of adsorbed water molecule and two bands at 1460 and 1380cm−1 are due to the carbonate species. The weak band at 1080cm−1 indicates the presence of symmetric (CO3)2−. The band at 1460cm−1 reveals that the inclusion of potassium promotes the formation of basic sites and the adsorption of carbon dioxide on the surface of La2O3-MgO. FT-IR spectra of virgin and used catalyst signify that there were no structural changes. It also indicates that there were no externally adsorbed species on the surface of the 2wt% K/La2O3-MgO catalyst. 3.1.3 Surface area and pore size analysis N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of samples are depicted in Fig. 3 . All the catalysts showed that they have the form of type-IV isotherm, and type H3 hysteresis loop, indicating that materials are mesoporous. The surface area, pore volume and average pore diameter of La2O3-MgO catalyst are 48m2 g−1, 0.13cm3 g−1 and 11nm, respectively (Table 1 ). With the increase in the loading of potassium, surface area as well as pore volume decreases. Cosimo et al. [43,44] reported that the introduction of alkali metals on MgO would result in a decrease in surface area and pore volume. The decline in pore volume and surface area upon potassium loading observed over La2O3-MgO and K/La2O3-MgO catalysts are in good agreement with the results of SEM and CO2-TPD analysis. The structural parameters of 2wt% K/La2O3-MgO and used 2wt% K/La2O3-MgO catalysts were observed almost the same. 3.1.4 TGA-DSC analysis TGA-DSC analysis of 2wt% K/La2O3-MgO catalyst was carried out from 50 to 700°C (Fig. 4 ). Two endothermic peaks were observed in DSC curve; first peak at 80–130°C due to the removal of water (humidity) and resulted in 8% weight loss. The second endothermic peak between 320°C and 400°C was due to the evolution of CO2 and decomposition of oxycarbonate corresponding to 12% weight loss to get stable oxide forms. The overall analysis shows around 20% weight loss and the catalyst was stable after 450°C up to 700°C. 3.1.5 CO2-TPD The basicity of all the samples was analyzed by using CO2-TPD. As showed in Fig. 5 La2O3-MgO catalyst CO2 desorption peaks were observed at 285°C and 470°C corresponding to moderate/strong basic sites, and the quantity of CO2 desorbed were 0.36 and 0.38mmolg−1. The introduction of potassium results in an increase in the desorption temperature and enhancement in the amount of CO2 desorption. 2wt% K/La2O3-MgO catalyst showed desorption peaks at 106, 324, 498 and 745°C corresponding to weak, moderate, strong, and super basic sites and the quantity of CO2 desorbed were 0.15, 0.21, 0.05 and 1.09mmolg−1, respectively. The desorption peak at 745°C is a clear indication of super basic sites which is due to the formation of K2O on the support as reported earlier [45]. Further increasing the concentration of potassium, there is a decline in the basicity of 3 and 4wt% K/La2O3-MgO catalysts (Table 2 ). This is due to the coverage of excess potassium on the surface of basic sites as well as blocking of some pores. The basicity of fresh and used catalyst showed almost similar results. There is no electronic effect of K as it is present in K2O as explained earlier by Uner et al. [30] where the electronic effect is not observed because potassium is not present in the form of zero valent species but as the oxide. In our case as evident by XRD and CO2-TPD analysis, potassium is present in the form of oxide. 3.1.6 SEM and EDX The SEM images of La2O3-MgO, 2wt% K/La2O3-MgO catalysts are shown in Fig. 6 . La2O3-MgO catalyst forms a spherical and dendritic structure. There was no agglomeration taking place after the introduction of 2wt% potassium on La2O3-MgO. Hence, it is assumed that with the low loading of potassium, a high dispersion was obtained and the La2O3-MgO support retained its original structure. The presence of potassium in catalyst was confirmed by EDX analysis (Table 3 ). 3.2 Catalytic reaction The reaction of mono-methylation of PAN by DMC using 2wt% K/La2O3-MgO catalyst is given in Scheme 1. 3.2.1 Efficacy of various catalysts Mixed oxides have been studied in a number of systems. Hence, a series of potassium loaded on La-Mg oxide catalysts were used to measure their efficacy in the mono-methylation of PAN (Fig. 7 ). A catalyst loading of 0.03g/cm3 based on the total volume of reaction mixture was employed at a mole ratio of 1: 30 PAN to DMC at 150°C and speed of 1000rpm. A series of catalysts such as MgO, La2O3, La2O3-MgO, 1wt% K/La2O3-MgO, 2wt% K/La2O3-MgO, 3wt% K/La2O3-MgO, and 4wt% K/La2O3-MgO were developed and characterized. The given reaction is 100% selective towards the mono-methylation of PAN. The conversion of PAN was greatly affected by loading of potassium on La2O3-MgO. The activity of MgO, La2O3, and La2O3-MgO were found to be very less due to less basicity. The activity of catalyst increases with increase in loading of potassium, and maximum conversion was obtained at 2wt%. It is due to increase of moderate and strong basic sites in promoted La2O3-MgO catalysts. Further increase of potassium loading on the La2O3-MgO leads to decrease in activity. The decline in the conversion of PAN could be attributed to the blocking of active sites due to excess amount of potassium and/or agglomeration of catalyst particles. The performance of 2wt% K/La2O3-FMgO catalyst for mono-methylation PAN with DMC was compared with the activity of previously reported literature [10,14,46–49] (Table 4 ). These values show that 2wt% K/La2O3-MgO is a much better catalyst reported so far. The highest activity of 2wt% K/La2O3-MgO catalyst is due to the presence of strong basic sites attributed to the polarization of DMC into an electrophile and activation of methylene group of PAN. For the mono-methylation reaction, the optimum potassium loading is 2wt%, in agreement with the results of BET surface area and CO2-TPD. 3.2.2 Effect of speed of agitation The effect of agitation speed was varied from 600 to 1200rpm at 150°C (Fig. 8 ). There is no change in the conversion of PAN at agitation speed from 1000 to 1200rpm. Thus, it indicated that there is no effect of mass transfer resistance beyond 1000rpm. Thus, all reactions were conducted at 1000rpm. Also, theoretical calculations were done as reported earlier to calculate mass transfer rate [39,50]. The calculated mass transfer rates were found to be very high in comparison of the reaction rate which confirms that there is no effect of external mass transfer resistance at and beyond 1000rpm. 3.2.3 Effect of catalyst loading In order to evaluate the influence of catalyst loading on conversion of PAN, loadings were studied from 0.01g/cm3 to 0.04g/cm3. Fig. 9 shows that up to 0.04g/cm3 there is an increase in PAN conversion due to the availability of active sites whereas from 0.03g/cm3 to 0.04g/cm3 there is no appreciable changes in the final conversion of PAN after 2h. Fig. 10 depicts initial rate of reaction (after 10min) increases linearly with the catalyst loading which confirms that mass transfer resistance is not acting. Wiesz-Prater criterion or modulus (CWP) was also calculated to find that the mono-methylation of PAN reaction was free from intra-particle diffusion limitation. The details related to these can be easily found in our earlier literature [50]. In this case, CWP value was found to be 3.26×10−3 which is very less than unity and hence there is no role of intra-particle diffusion resistance on the overall rate of reaction. 3.2.4 Effect of mole ratio of PAN to DMC Fig. 11 shows the effect of mole ratio of PAN to DMC from 1:10 to 1:40 over 2wt% K/La2O3-MgO catalyst. PAN conversion was increased with increasing molar ratio because the excess amount of DMC helps to solubilize the formed product and makes catalytic sites free for the reaction. At 1:10mol ratio, the conversion was 51% which increased to 100% at 1:30mol ratio. Hence mole ratio of 1:30 was selected to be optimum and used for further studies. 3.2.5 Effect of temperature The conversion of PAN was studied from 130 to 160°C keeping other parameters at optimum conditions (Fig. 12 ). The increase in temperature resulted in an increase in the initial rate of reaction and conversion substantially which suggested that reaction was kinetically controlled. The final conversion of PAN increased with increase in temperature and after 150°C there was no significant change in final conversion. Hence 150°C was selected for optimum temperature for mono-methylation of PAN reaction. 3.2.6 Reaction mechanism and mathematical model The possible mono-methylation mechanism of PAN with DMC on basic sites of 2wt% K/La2O3-MgO catalyst is shown in Scheme 2 . Two wt% K/La2O3-MgO catalyst is super basic in nature due to the loading of potassium on La2O3-MgO mixed oxides. Firstly, PAN gets adsorbed on the basic sites of the catalyst. It is completely activated by deprotonation of active methylene group by the basic sites to make reactive carbanion, followed by an attack of methyl carbon of adsorbed DMC on adjacent basic sites. The intermediate formed undergoes rearrangement to give the desired 2-PPN followed by the evolution of methanol and carbon dioxide. A mathematical model was developed using LHHW mechanism as same reported in the recent literature [39,51,52]. Mono-methylation of PAN (A) with DMC (B) occurs by strong adsorption of PAN on basic sites leading to the formation of 2-PPN. The details of derivation are provided in supplementary information. The rate of reaction of PAN can be given as: (1) − r A = − d C A d t = C A 0 d X A d t = k R 2 w C A 0 ( 1 − X A ) C B 0 DMC was taken in far molar excess over PAN ( C B 0 > C A 0 ), it becomes a pseudo-first order equation which can be integrated as follows: (2) − ln ( 1 − X A ) = k 1 w t where k 1 = k R 2 C B 0 is the pseudo-first order constant, cm3 g-cat−1 s−1. A plot of −ln (1-XA) versus t at various temperatures gives an excellent fit and shows the reaction is pseudo-first order (Fig. 13 ). The rate constant values were calculated and activation energy of the reaction estimated from Arrhenius plot (Fig. 14 ). The apparent energy of activation was found to be 13.77kcal/mol. 3.2.7 Reusability of catalyst The reusability of 2wt% K/La2O3-MgO catalyst was tested for mono-methylation of PAN under the optimized conditions: temperature 150°C, catalyst loading 0.03g/cm3, speed of agitation 1000rpm, the reaction time 2h. The catalyst was filtered, washed with methanol and dried at 120°C after every experiment. Fig. 15 depicts that 2wt% K/La2O3-MgO catalyst is reusable for four cycles with an insignificant decrease in activity. Reused catalyst was characterized to see if there were any changes that occurred in the catalyst. XRD, FTIR, CO2-TPD and surface area analysis confirmed that there were no significant changes in the morphology and structure of catalyst after reuse. Thus, the prepared catalyst is stable. Further, the hot filtration test was also conducted to study leaching of active sites, if any. Reaction was stopped after 30min and the catalyst filtered. The reactor was washed to get rid of any traces of catalyst. The reaction was continued further for 2h. The slight increase in conversion was noticed from 42 to 45% conversion which can be experimental error. The ICP-AES analysis was also done and the samples of the reaction mixture were tested for the presence of metal ions in a reaction mixture. K ion content was found less than 0.0003ppm of K which is negligible. This confirmed the strong interaction between K2O and support i.e. La2O3-MgO. As reported by Noiroj et al. [41] who claimed that nature or type of support plays an important role in preventing a leaching of active species, in the current work La2O3-MgO not only plays the role of base catalyst but also act as a good support to prevent the leaching of potassium. 3.2.8 Substrate study After successful preparation and characterization of 2wt% K/La2O3-MgO catalyst, we examined the scope and limitation of this catalyst in the O-methylation of various phenols such as phenol, 4-methoxyphenol, 4-nitrophenol, 4-hydroxybenzaldehyde and 4-tert-butyl phenol with DMC under otherwise similar conditions (Table 5 ). The electron rich substitute such as OCH3 and tert-butyl at para position on phenol gave slightly less conversion towards desired products (Table 5 entries 2–3). Electron withdrawing substituents such as NO2 and CHO on phenol can increase the conversion of reaction towards the desired products (Table 5 entries 4–5). It can be seen that the catalyst gave excellent conversion of 94–100% in all the phenols. 98% conversion was achieved for 4-anisaldehyde which has important use in fragrance and flavour industry. Reaction of phenol with DMC gives 98% conversion of anisole which find application in synthesis of natural and artificial fragrances. Completion of the reaction was monitored by GC and products were confirmed by GC–MS. 4 Conclusions Different loadings of potassium (1%, 2%, 3% and 4% wt) promoted on La2O3-MgO catalysts were synthesized, characterized with various techniques and screened. Potassium promoted mixed oxides showed much higher catalytic activity than the corresponding pure La2O3-MgO mixed oxide in the selective mono-methylation of PAN with DMC, due to increase in moderate, strong, super basic sites. Moreover, loading of potassium on La2O3-MgO changes the structural properties like pore volume and surface area, and it gives higher conversion towards the desired product. 2wt% K/La2O3-MgO catalyst was found to be the best for the methylation of PAN. By using this catalyst, we studied various parameters systematically to establish kinetics. The maximum conversion of PAN was achieved at 150°C, PAN to DMC mole ratio 1:30 and catalyst loading 0.03g/cm3. The catalyst is reusable up to four cycles. The activation energy for mono-methylation of PAN was calculated as 13.77kcal/mol. The optimized conditions were very effective for methylation of various phenols. So the catalyst is tolerable to various functional groups present in the molecule and has given well to excellent conversion for the methylation reaction. coredata.dc:description: Mono-methylated products of phenyl acetonitrile (PAN) are in demand for the preparation of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAID) such as Ketoprofen, Ibuprofen and Naproxen. 2-Phenylpropionitrile is prepared from PAN and finds uses in pharmaceutical industry. Herein, we report a novel catalyst potassium promoted lanthanum-magnesium oxide as well as a novel reaction using it. It is used for the first time for the selective mono-methylation of phenylacetonitrile to 2-phenylpropionitrile with dimethyl carbonate as a methylating agent. A variety of catalysts were synthesized, characterized such as MgO, La2O3, La2O3-MgO and potassium (1–4wt%) on La2O3-MgO and used in mono-methylation of phenylacetonitrile with dimethyl carbonate (DMC). Two wt% K/La2O3-MgO catalyst was the best and showed 100% conversion of phenylacetonitrile and 100% selectivity of 2-phenyl propionitrile at mole ratio of PAN: DMC of 1:30 at 150°C in 2h. The characterization of fresh and used 2wt% K/La2O3-MgO was done using different techniques such as FTIR, SEM, TGA-DSC, CO2-TPD, XRD, and BET surface area analysis. Two wt% K/La2O3-MgO catalyst was used to study the reaction mechanism and a kinetic model developed using LHHW type of mechanism with all species being weakly adsorbed. The apparent activation for mono-methylation of phenylacetonitrile to 2-phenylpropionitrile was found to be 13.77kcal/mol.
coredata.dc:title: Potassium modified La-Mg mixed oxide as active and selective catalyst for mono-methylation of phenylacetonitrile with dimethyl carbonate
